title: The Surprising Power of Atomic Habits
summary: Small habits compound over time in the same way that interest compounds in a bank account. Positive habits multiply your potential and negative ones quietly sabotage you. The chapter introduces the central idea: your outcomes are a lagging measure of your habits. Long-term success depends on consistently performing small improvements.
keyIdeas: Habits are the compound interest of self-improvement.
Tiny changes can lead to massive differences over time.
Success is not a goal—it’s a system of everyday habits.
Your current results are not as important as your current trajectory.
Time magnifies the margin between good and bad habits.
You don’t rise to the level of your goals—you fall to the level of your systems.
Small habits are easier to maintain and more sustainable.
examples: Saving $1 per day grows into meaningful wealth over years.
Reading one page a day turns into dozens of books per year.
Eating 100 extra calories daily leads to significant weight gain over time.
exercises: Identify one positive habit you want to start and shrink it to a 1-minute version.
Write one negative habit you want to eliminate and describe its long-term cost.
reflections: What small habit could dramatically change your life if compounded for five years?
Are your current habits pulling you toward your goals or away from them?
